title: Here‚Äôs how Apple Intelligence keeps privacy in mind versus the competition
description: Artificial intelligence has obviously been the industry craze for the past couple years. While large language models are incredibly capable, they‚Äôve always come with a bit of a compromise: privacy. Ultimately, you‚Äôre still using a model hosted in the cloud, and all of your conversations are stored on some server. Apple‚Äôs always had privacy at the core of its products ‚Äì so in the months leading up to the debut of Apple‚Äôs AI features, many people wondered: how would Apple handle it? Today, we delve into exactly how. more‚Ä¶
author: Michael Burkhardt

title: iOS 26‚Äôs Photos app has a helpful new feature for events: Here‚Äôs how it works
description: At WWDC25, Apple introduced a few new capabilities to the Photos app for iOS 26. Most notably, it reintroduces a tab bar layout after last year‚Äôs controversial single-page redesign. It also allows you to create spatial scenes from existing photos. On top of those headlining features, there‚Äôs another underlying feature in the Photos app for iOS 26 that a lot of users might appreciate, and thats event details. Let‚Äôs explain. more‚Ä¶
author: Michael Burkhardt

title: M5 iPad Pro to gain dual front-facing cameras in late 2025
description: The M5 iPad Pro, currently expected to launch in October 2025, will come with more than just a new chip and a thinner bezel: Apple will add a second front-facing camera in the formerly traditional portrait orientation.The M5 iPad Pro will likely sport two front-facing cameras in vertical and horizontal positions.The next iPad Pro will most prominently feature the M5 processor. The forthcoming update is said to have been in testing since at least March.However, a new report says another big change is coming. Apple will add a second front-facing camera in order to make it easier for users to unlock the device when using it in its traditional vertical position, according to Bloomberg. Rumor Score: ü§Ø Likely Continue Reading on AppleInsider | Discuss on our Forums

title: Deals: Get the Apple Pencil 2 for $109.99 ($19 Off) and 512GB M1 MacBook Air for $1,099.99 ($149 Off)
description: Today we're tracking a pair of deals, one on the Apple Pencil 2 and one on the 2020 M1 MacBook Air. These sales include the current best price online for the Apple Pencil 2, and an all-time low price on the MacBook Air. Note: MacRumors is an affiliate partner with some of these vendors. When you click a link and make a purchase, we may receive a small payment, which helps us keep the site running. Apple Pencil 2 Firstly, Woot has the Apple Pencil 2 for $109.99, down from $129.00. This sale isn't the lowest price we've ever tracked on this accessory, as it's been down to $99.00 in previous sales earlier this year, but it's still a solid second-best deal if you're looking to purchase an Apple Pencil 2 this week. $19 OFFApple Pencil 2 for $109.99 The Apple Pencil 2 is compatible with the new iPad mini 6, but not the new 10.2-inch iPad. For that tablet, only the original Apple Pencil is supported. MacBook Air Amazon today has the 512GB M1 MacBook Air for $1,099.99, down from $1,249.00. This is a match of the all-time low price on this model of the 2020 MacBook Air, and it's available in Space Gray and Silver. You'll see this sale price reflected on the checkout screen, once an automatic coupon is applied to your order. While the Gold option won't be available until around October 1, you can still purchase a Gold MacBook Air today at this discounted price ahead of the delayed shipping date. $149 OFFM1 MacBook Air (512GB) for $1,099.99 The 256GB model is on sale as well, available for $849.99, down from $999.00. All three colors are discounted for this model, but none are in stock today. This is still the lowest price we've ever tracked for the 256GB MacBook Air, so if you're willing to wait a few weeks, it's worth locking in this price while it's available. You can find even more discounts on other MacBooks by visiting our Best Deals guide for MacBook Pro and MacBook Air. description: Macworld Cloud storage should do more than hold your files ‚Äî it should protect them. That‚Äôs exactly what Internxt was built to do, and right now, new users can grab¬†a lifetime subscription to 20TB of Internxt Cloud Storage¬†for just $389.97 (down from $4,900). No monthly fees. No renewal reminders. Just total control, forever. Internxt is a privacy-first alternative to the usual cloud giants. Everything you store is end-to-end encrypted and broken into smaller pieces for maximum security. Your data isn‚Äôt just stored safely ‚Äî it‚Äôs protected by zero-knowledge encryption, meaning only you can access your files. Not even Internxt can peek. And with apps for Windows, Mac, Linux, iOS, Android, and web browsers, you can access your cloud from pretty much any device, anywhere. It‚Äôs intuitive, speedy, and includes¬†Post-Quantum Encryption, so your data stays protected even as tech evolves. Whether you‚Äôre a small business backing up sensitive documents, a video editor saving huge project files, or just someone with a growing media library, this gives you serious space without the long-term, ongoing subscription drain. title: Windows 11 Pro for under $10? Yes, it‚Äôs a deal so good you might not believe it
description: Macworld Even the most dedicated Mac users sometimes need to dip into Windows, whether it‚Äôs for cross-platform development, gaming, running a virtual machine, or just staying flexible for work. For those moments, having a reliable Windows license on hand is key. Right now through July 20, StackSocial is offering a¬†lifetime license to¬†Microsoft Windows 11 Pro¬†for just $9.97‚Äîa massive drop from the usual $199 price tag. This deal includes the full Pro version, not a stripped-down edition, with features like enhanced encryption, remote desktop access, BitLocker, and improved virtualization support. Windows 11 Pro is built for productivity and performance, with a streamlined interface, better window snapping, and deep support for hybrid workflows. It‚Äôs especially handy for users running Parallels, VMware, or dual-boot setups through Boot Camp. Another bonus? There‚Äôs¬†Copilot, the AI-powered assistant¬†that can answer queries, generate content, and even help you prepare for certification exams. This is a one-time purchase, meaning there are no subscriptions or recurring fees. Just a license key and lifetime access. Setup is simple, and once it‚Äôs installed, the license is locked to your machine permanently. Whether for work, testing, or just keeping all software bases covered, this is one of the easiest and most affordable ways to add Windows to your macOS ecosystem. Don‚Äôt wait to grab your¬†Windows 11 Pro lifetime license¬†for just $9.97 until July 20 at 11:59 p.m. PT. Supplies are limited and no coupon is needed. author: OSXDaily

title: Retreating to Safety
description: Ten years ago, Apple‚Äôs Phil Schiller surprised Apple enthusiasts and developers by walking out on stage at John Gruber‚Äôs The Talk Show Live WWDC event and giving an open, human, honest interview to a somewhat jaded community. I wrote this in response: Both Apple and Phil Schiller himself took a huge risk in doing this. That they agreed at all is a noteworthy gift to this community of long-time enthusiasts, many of whom have felt under-appreciated as the company has grown. [‚Ä¶] Phil‚Äôs appearance on the show was warm, genuine, informative, and entertaining. It was human. And humanizing the company and its decisions, especially to developers ‚Äî remember, developer relations is all under Phil ‚Äî might be worth the PR risk. This started a ten-year run of interviews by Apple executives on The Talk Show every year at WWDC that proved to be great, surprisingly safe PR for Apple. No executive ever said something they shouldn‚Äôt have (they‚Äôre pros), no sensational or negative news stories ever resulted from them, and Apple‚Äôs enthusiastic fans and developers felt seen, heard, and appreciated. *¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†*¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†* For unspecified reasons, Apple has declined to participate this year, ending what had become a beloved tradition in our community ‚Äî and I can‚Äôt help but suspect that it won‚Äôt come back. (A lot has changed in the meantime.) Maybe Apple has good reasons. Maybe not. We‚Äôll see what their WWDC PR strategy looks like in a couple of weeks. In the absence of any other information, it‚Äôs easy to assume that Apple no longer wants its executives to be interviewed in a human, unscripted, unedited context that may contain hard questions, and that Apple no longer feels it necessary to show their appreciation to our community and developers in this way. I hope that‚Äôs either not the case, or it doesn‚Äôt stay the case for long. This will be the first WWDC I‚Äôm not attending since 2009 (excluding the remote 2020 one, of course). Given my realizations about my relationship with Apple and how they view developers, I‚Äôve decided that it‚Äôs best for me to take a break this year, gain some perspective, and decide what my future relationship should look like. Maybe Apple‚Äôs leaders are doing that, too.

title: Ten years of Overcast: A new foundation
description: Today, on the tenth anniversary of Overcast 1.0, I‚Äôm happy to launch a complete rewrite and redesign of most of the iOS app, built to carry Overcast into the next decade ‚Äî and hopefully beyond. Like podcasts better than blog posts? Listen to ATP #596 for more! What‚Äôs new Much faster, more responsive, more reliable, and more accessible. Modern design, optimized for easily-reached controls on today‚Äôs phone sizes. Improvements throughout, such as undoing large seeks, new playlist-priority options, easier navigation, and more. What‚Äôs not Most features. Overcast is still Overcast! The audio engine. It‚Äôs the best part of Overcast, and still leads the industry in sound quality, silence skipping, and volume normalization. (More soon!) The business. I‚Äôm still a one-person operation, with no funding or external ownership, serving only my customers. My principles. I always want to make the best podcast app, and I‚Äôll never disrespect your time, attention, or privacy. What‚Äôs gone Streaming. Most big podcasts now use dynamic ad insertion, which causes bugs and problems for streaming playback.1 Downloading episodes completely before they begin playback is much more reliable. Tapping a non-downloaded episode will now open the playback screen, download it, then start playback. It works similarly to the way streaming did before, but playback begins after the download completes, not after a portion of it is buffered. On today‚Äôs fast networks, this usually only takes a few extra seconds. And in the near future, I‚Äôll be adding smarter options and more control over selective downloading of episodes to further improve the experience for people who don‚Äôt automatically download every episode. What‚Äôs next The last few missing features from the old app, such as Shortcuts support, storage management, and OPML. These are absent now, but will return soon. More options for downloading and deleting episodes. Upgrading the Apple Watch app to the new, faster sync engine. (The Watch app is currently unchanged from the previous one.) And, of course, more features, including some of your most-requested features over the last decade. Getting this rewrite out the door was a monumental task. Thank you for your patience as I work through this list! Why? Most of Overcast‚Äôs core code was 10 years old, which made it cumbersome or impossible to easily move with the times, adopt new iOS functionality, or add new features, especially as one person. That‚Äôs why there haven‚Äôt been many new features or changes in years. You saw it, and I saw it. I wasn‚Äôt able to serve my customers as well as I wanted. For Overcast to have a future, it needed a modern foundation for its second decade. I‚Äôve spent the past 18 months rebuilding most of the app with Swift, SwiftUI, Blackbird, and modern Swift concurrency. Now, development is rapidly accelerating. I‚Äôm more responsive, iterating more quickly, and ultimately making the app much better. Thank you all so much for the first decade of Overcast. Here‚Äôs to the next one. Dynamic ad insertion (DAI) splices ads into each download, and no two downloads are guaranteed to have the same number or duration of ads. So, for example, if the first half of an episode downloads, then the download fails, and it downloads the second half with another request, the combined audio may jump forward or back at the halfway mark, losing or repeating content.¬†‚Ü©Ô∏é

description: Dave installed the latest beta of watchOS and found a new gesture that he really likes. I have one that I use a lot as well, so I'm not sure I'll change. Apple TV+ shows recieved an incredible amount of nominations for this year's Emmy Awards. The new tvOS now allows users to switch the keyboard to a grid, which is a welcome change. Follow this podcast Show Notes: Cal Raleigh, man of the people, The Big Dumper, wins Home Run Derby watchOS 26. Flick it Apple gets an astonishing 81 Emmy nominations Apple TV lets you change your search keyboard from linear (one line, across the screen) to a grid ChatGPT and other AI services are basically killing @Iconfactory Shows and movies we're watching Mobland, Paramount+ Ballard, Prime Video, from the Bosch universe Ya Never Know, Tom Selleck autobiography

title: ‚àû The Dalrymple Report: AI talent, Meta, and COO
description: The turmoil at Apple is not new, but what is new is how some of the companies top AI engineers are leaving the company. The latest was lured away by Meta, who have just invested $3.5 billion in its artificial intelligence projects. Apple's longtime Chief Operating Officer, Jeff Williams, has announced he's retiring. Follow this podcast Brought to you by: LinkedIn Jobs: LinkedIn Jobs helps you find the candidates you want to talk to, faster. Did you know every week, nearly 40 million job seekers visit LinkedIn? Post your job for free at LinkedIn.com/DALRYMPLE. Terms and conditions apply. Show Notes: Apple faces AI talent turmoil as senior Siri researcher departs Apple announces chief operating officer transition Apple Loses Key AI Executive to Meta's Multimillion-Dollar Hiring Spree Meta Invests $3.5 Billion in World‚Äôs Largest Eye-Wear Maker Shows and movies we're watching Black Snow, AMC+ Kleo, Netflix MurderBot, Apple TV+
